What does the Disability Advisory Services at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus focus on?
The Disability Advisory Services focus on reasonable adjustments of accessible services to help students complete their courses as independently as possible.

Disability is defined as seen disability (physical, visual, or hearing impairment) and unseen disability (mental health challenges or long-term medical conditions).

Can you provide more information about the students from the University of Nottingham Malaysia who participated in the James Dyson Award?

A group of four MEng students; Jason Lee Jun Wei, Lim Dao Kun, Lim Jian Ching and Wong Ee Chew from the Department of Mechanical, Materials and Manufacturing Engineering (M3) at the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM) has emerged as the national runners-up in the James Dyson Award Malaysia 2019 on 19 September 2019.

The winning entry of the students was a floating sea bin, titled 'Litterid', which was designed with the concept of a drone in the water to capture and drag plastic back to the shore.

The prototype designed by the students had the capacity to carry up to 46 litres of plastic and a manoeuvring speed of 0.5 m/s.

The James Dyson Award is an international design award that celebrates, encourages, and inspires the next generation of design engineers.

The workshop included four sessions that required participants to write their goals, break them down into details, simplify them, and develop action plans.

What is the focus of the Tropical Conservation Ecology Lab at the University of Nottingham Malaysia and their main project?

Why are elephants considered intelligent land mammals?
After the great apes, elephants are considered to be the world’s most intelligent land mammal.
In what ways do elephants display their intelligence?
Elephants are known to have remarkable memories and can make and use tools like using leafy branches as fly swatters.
How do elephants contribute to the ecosystem?
Wild elephants help to maintain the forest’s ecosystem dynamics by playing a vital role in seed dispersal and nutrient cycling, known as mega-gardeners of the forest.
What physical characteristics differentiate Asian and African elephants?

Asian elephants can grow up to 2.7 meters in height with a weight of between 3,000 and 6,000 kilograms, while African elephants can grow up to 3 meters in height and weigh between 4,000 and 7,500 kilograms.
I read that GPS collars have been placed on wild elephants in Peninsular Malaysia. Why was this done?
GPS collars were used by MEME and PERHILITAN to track the movement of over 50 wild elephants to understand their range and how infrastructures like roads impact their movement.
How do roads affect elephant movement, according to the information?

Roads that cut across wildlife habitats can become barriers for elephants, hindering their movement from one side to the other. The presence of oncoming traffic also increases the risk of elephant mortality.
What measures can be taken to reduce conflict between humans and elephants due to habitat fragmentation?
To mitigate conflict and prevent further loss of elephant range, it's important to support farmers so they can co-exist with wild elephants in shared landscapes.

Could you tell me about Dr Sumit Mandal's research interests and achievements at the University of Nottingham Malaysia Campus?

Dr Sumit Mandal, Associate Professor in the School of Politics, History and International Relations, is intrigued by the era of interconnectedness between Malaysia, Indonesia, and Singapore. He situates the Malay world against the broader backdrop of the Indian Ocean to observe patterns of trade, migration, and cultural exchange. Dr Mandal published the book 'Becoming Arab: Creole histories and modern identity in the Malay world' with Cambridge University Press in 2018. This book explores Arab communities in the Malay world in the 16-18th centuries, tracing their origins to Hadhrami Arabs migrating from Yemen. In 2020, 'Becoming Arab' was awarded the Harry J. Benda book prize by the US-based Association for Asian Studies for Dr Mandal's outstanding scholarship in Southeast Asian studies.

Can you tell me more about the elephant-tiger sounds used to deter raids?

What is HSK and what does it test?

HSK (Hanyu Shuiping Kaoshi) is an international standardised exam that tests and rates Chinese language proficiency. It consists of six levels, from 1 to 6, assessing different language proficiency skills.
How does the HSK Speaking Test (HSKK) differ from the regular HSK exam?
The HSK Speaking Test (HSKK) assesses the test takers' oral Chinese abilities and has three levels: Primary, Intermediate, and Advanced.
Who can take the HSK exam and why is the certificate important?

Non-native Chinese speakers, including Chinese Malaysians, can take the HSK exam to evaluate their Chinese language proficiency. The HSK certificate is essential for educational decisions, employment recruitment, and improving Chinese language proficiency.
How can one prepare for the HSK exam?
Preparation for the HSK exam involves self-study, language courses, and practice exams; resources like textbooks, online courses, and study guides are helpful.
Is there an expiration date for the HSK certificate?
The HSK certificate does not have an expiration date, but validity requirements may vary for different organisations and employers.
What can candidates do to improve their scores in the HSK exam?
Candidates can retake the HSK exam to improve their scores and proficiency level; there are no restrictions on the number of retakes.

The entry requirements include a master's degree with a distinction or merit grade, plus an upper second-class honors degree or a first-class honors degree in computer science or a relevant area. English language requirements also apply with minimum scores in IELTS, TOEFL, PTE, or MUET exams.

That's interesting! What event is the University of Nottingham Malaysia proud to announce for 2025?
The University of Nottingham Malaysia is proud to announce the return of the UNAM-UNM Tengku Ahmad Rithauddeen Award Essay Competition in 2025!
Who can participate in the essay competition and what are the criteria for the submissions?

The competition is open to all students aged 17 to 23 years in Malaysia. Submissions must be by a single author and focus on the topic 'Meaningful Education for a Nation's Progress, Innovation, and Inclusiveness.' The submissions should be between 1,500 to 2,000 words and meet various criteria like originality, understanding of education issues, and a persuasive call to action.
What are the prizes for the winners, and how are the winning submissions selected?

The prizes include RM 2,000.00 for the first prize, RM 1,500.00 for the second prize, and RM 1,000.00 for the third prize. The winning submissions will be chosen by a panel of judges from the University of Nottingham and the United Nations Association of Malaysia.
What are the requirements for entries to the competition?

Entries to the competition must be unique and original in content. They should not be published elsewhere or submitted to other essay competitions. Plagiarized entries will be disqualified. A bibliography acknowledging references is necessary.
When is the deadline for submission?
The deadline for submission is 02 April 2025, which falls on a Wednesday.

Can you tell me more about the challenges to food security in the region and the FSSIDS network?

The challenges to food security in the region include rapid population growth, urbanization, climate change disasters, and breakdowns in traditional social safety nets. The FSSIDS network emphasizes South-South Learning and Cooperation, stressing the importance of SDG 17 for sustainable development in food systems. It aims to connect stakeholders, facilitate discussions, establish new opportunities, and encourage interdisciplinary collaborations in food systems in South-East Asia and South Pacific Islands.
Who are some of the countries and members involved in the FSSIDS community?

Countries such as Australia, Fiji, Indonesia, Malaysia, Papua New Guinea, Philippines, Samoa, Singapore, Thailand, United Kingdom, and Vietnam are part of the FSSIDS community. The FSSIDS Working Group includes members like Chin Chiew Foan, Christina Supramaniam, Pau Loke Show, Ee Von Goh, Andrew Clarke, Peter Noy, and Lexi Earl.

That's interesting! How is the BSc in Nutrition ranked?
The BSc in Nutrition program is ranked #2 among UK universities in the nutrition and food sciences subject area according to the Guardian University Guide 2025.
Is the Nutrition program accredited?
Yes, the BSc Nutrition program is accredited by the Association for Nutrition (AfN) in the UK and the Malaysian Allied Health Professions Council (MAHPC).
What’s the main difference between a degree in nutrition and dietetics?

A degree in nutrition prepares students for diverse roles in clinical settings, public health organizations, communities, and industries, while dietetics primarily focuses on careers in clinical and hospital settings.
What career opportunities do graduates in Nutrition have?

That sounds interesting! What about studying Biotechnology? What does the course at the University of Nottingham Malaysia offer?

The BSc (Hons) Biotechnology programme at the University of Nottingham Malaysia integrates hands-on laboratory experience with theoretical knowledge and offers specializations in Industrial, Medical/Pharmaceutical, and Agricultural Biotechnology.
How long is the Biotechnology program, and who teaches it?

The BSc (Hons) Biotechnology course is a 3-year program accredited by the Malaysian Qualifications Agency and is taught by award-winning and internationally recognized professors from the School of Biosciences.
That's great! How does the university gather feedback from students regarding their courses?
One of the main methods is through anonymised Student Evaluation. They use a tool called Evaluate to capture Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) and Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) data.
What exactly is SET, and why is it important?

Student Evaluation of Teaching (SET) evaluates an individual lecturer, usually focusing on a specific teaching session. The scores are considered when the lecturer applies for promotion or confirmation in their employment.
And what about the comments from these evaluations?
The open-ended comments from SET remain confidential to the staff member being evaluated, ensuring privacy.
What insights does the SEM provide?

Student Evaluation of Modules (SEM) assesses the overall learning experience for an entire module, focusing on learning resources and outcomes. Feedback from SEM is considered during the module review process to improve the module for future delivery.

What were some of the highlights of their presentations?

Dr. Badeeb teaches modules such as International Finance, Financial Instruments and Markets, Econometrics, Business Economics, Market Structure & Competition, and Games & Strategies.

What are some important visa requirements for international students?

What happens if an international student fails the medical examination?

Are there any health guidelines students should be aware of before traveling?

Why are the discovered mussels considered rare, and what threatens their habitat?

What is the latest development regarding the University of Nottingham Malaysia's ownership?
The University of Nottingham will buy out its Malaysian partner Boustead Holdings Berhad (BHB) for £23.5m to secure the long-term future of the University of Nottingham Malaysia (UNM).
How will the University of Nottingham Malaysia be managed after the buyout?
The University of Nottingham Malaysia will be run as the majority shareholder by the University through a wholly-owned Malaysian subsidiary.
When did the University of Nottingham Malaysia campus relocate to its current site, and how has it grown since then?
The University of Nottingham Malaysia campus relocated to a 48-hectare site in Semenyih in 2005. It now has more than 650 staff and 5,200 students from the ASEAN region and beyond.

The University of Nottingham has 42,000 students across campuses in the UK, China, and Malaysia.
